intro: Acacia ammophila, commonly known as the coastal acacia, is a shrub native to coastal areas of southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, feathery leaves that are adapted to reduce water loss in arid environments. The plant produces yellow flowers in clusters, which are followed by pod-like fruits containing seeds. It plays an important role in stabilizing sandy soils along coastal dunes. Acacia ammophila is also valued for its ability to provide habitat and food for various desert animals.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees found mainly in tropical and subtropical regions, known for their acacia-like foliage and sometimes thorny stems. Its species is Acacia ammophila, a specific type of acacia that is adapted to sandy environments and is often found in coastal dunes.
